RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduação em Engenharia de Infraestrutura Aeronáutica pelo Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (1997), especialização em Engenharia Sanitária e Ambiental pela Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (2000), mestrado em Saúde Pública pela Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (2003), doutorado co-tutela em em Geomateriais pela Université Paris-Est Marne la Vallée (2008) e em Engenharia Química pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (PEQ 2008). Atua em projetos de Saneamento, Tratamento de Efluentes e Sustentabilidade nos seguintes temas: Água Fria, Água Quente, Contraincêndio, Aquecimento Solar, Águas Pluviais, Aproveitamento de Águas Pluviais, Energia, Instalações Elétricas, Redes de Água e de Esgoto, Estações de Tratamento de Água, Estações de Tratamento de Esgoto e Estações de Tratamento de Efluente Industriais e Processos Oxidativos Avançados. Paralelamente, lecionou cadeiras de Tratamento de Água, Sistemas de Esgoto (ENSP) e Poluição Atmosférica (UNISAU). Em 2012, recebeu a Láurea "PROF. LACAZ NETTO" como Co-orientador do melhor Trabalho de Graduação do Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica em 2011. Desde 2012, atua como instrutor do Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica. A partir de 2020, foi efetivado como Professor do Magistério Superior, onde atualmente leciona as disciplinas de Instalações Prediais, Saneamento, Tratamento de Água, Uso eficiente de Água em aeroportos, Energia Solar em Edificações na graduação e na pós-graduação da Divisão de Engenharia Civil do ITA.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Graduated in Aeronautical Infrastructure Engineering from Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (1997), specialization in Sanitary and Environmental Engineering from the State University of Rio de Janeiro (2000), master's degree in Public Health from Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (2003), PhD co-tutelage in Geomaterials by Université Paris-Est Marne la Vallée (2008) and in Chemical Engineering by the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (PEQ 2008). Operates in Sanitation, Water-Wastewater Treatments and Sustainability projects in the following subjects: Water, Hot Water, Fire, Solar Heating, Rainwater, Use of Rainwater, Energy, Electrical Installations, Water and Sewerage Networks, Water Treatment Plants Water, Sewage Treatment Plants and Industrial Effluent Treatment Plants and Advanced Oxidative Processes. At the same time, he taught courses in Water Treatment, Sewage Systems (ENSP) and Air Pollution (UNISAU). In 2012, he received the Laureate "PROF. LACAZ NETTO" as Co-supervisor of the best Graduate Work at the Technological Institute of Aeronautics in 2011. Since 2012, he has been an instructor at the Technological Institute of Aeronautics. From 2020, he became effective as a Professor of the Higher Magisterium, where he currently teaches the disciplines of Building Installations, Sanitation, Water Treatment, Efficient Water Use in Airports, Solar Energy in Buildings in undergraduate and graduate courses in the Engineering Division ITA Civil.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Phenol degradation by advanced electrochemical oxidation process electro-Fenton using a carbon felt cathode
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Phenol degradation by advanced electrochemical oxidation process electro-Fenton using a carbon felt cathode

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Oxidation of phenol in aqueous media by electro-Fenton process using carbon felt cathode has been studied. The salts of iron, cobalt,
manganese, and copper were used to provide the metal cations as catalyst of Fenton reaction to produce hydroxyl radicals. 104 M of soluble
iron(II) sulfate salt supplied the optimum catalytic condition, allowing to remove 100% of total organic carbon (TOC) of aqueous phenol solutions.
The main reaction intermediates formed during electro-Fenton treatment were identified as hydroquinone, p-benzoquinone, and catechol.
Carboxylic acids such as maleic, fumaric, succinic, glyoxylic, oxalic, and formic were predominantly identified as end products, before complete
mineralization. The absolute rate constant of phenol degradation by hydroxyl radicals was obtained in acid medium (2.5 < pH < 3.0), being equal
to (2.62 IC=0.23) x 10^9 (M.s)^(-1) . Experiments with electro-Fenton oxidation of each aromatic intermediate allowed to propose a complete mineralization pathway.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Oxidation of phenol in aqueous media by electro-Fenton process using carbon felt cathode has been studied. The salts of iron, cobalt,
manganese, and copper were used to provide the metal cations as catalyst of Fenton reaction to produce hydroxyl radicals. 104 M of soluble
iron(II) sulfate salt supplied the optimum catalytic condition, allowing to remove 100% of total organic carbon (TOC) of aqueous phenol solutions.
The main reaction intermediates formed during electro-Fenton treatment were identified as hydroquinone, p-benzoquinone, and catechol.
Carboxylic acids such as maleic, fumaric, succinic, glyoxylic, oxalic, and formic were predominantly identified as end products, before complete
mineralization. The absolute rate constant of phenol degradation by hydroxyl radicals was obtained in acid medium (2.5 < pH < 3.0), being equal
to (2.62 IC=0.23) x 10^9 (M.s)^(-1) . Experiments with electro-Fenton oxidation of each aromatic intermediate allowed to propose a complete mineralization pathway.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Reaction sequence for the mineralization of the short-chain carboxylic acids usually formed upon cleavage of aromatics during electrochemical Fenton treatment
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Reaction sequence for the mineralization of the short-chain carboxylic acids usually formed upon cleavage of aromatics during electrochemical Fenton treatment

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Electrochemical Fenton treatment of aromatic pollutants in aqueous medium always leads to the formation of short-chain carboxylic acids, which account for the slower degradation rate at the final stages of the process. In order to gain further insight into the fate of such compounds, bulk electrolyses of 200 mL aqueous solutions of eleven C1?C4 carboxylics, namely formic, glyoxylic, oxalic, acetic, glycolic, pyruvic, malonic, maleic, fumaric, succinic and malic acid have been carried out by electro-Fenton process with 0.1mM Fe2+ as catalyst, at room temperature and pH 3.0, applying a constant current and using an open and undivided cell equipped with a carbon-felt cathode and a Pt anode. In situ cathodic electrogeneration of Fenton?s reagent leads to the formation of the very oxidizing species hydroxyl radical (?OH) in the medium, allowing the degradation and total mineralization of all carboxylics studied. Various goals have been accomplished: (a) identification of the degradation intermediates for each carboxylic acid and study of their time course, (b) discussion and proposal of the reaction mechanisms under the action of ?OH/O2, (c) analysis of the decay kinetics and determination of the absolute rate constants, which agree well with those available in literature for processes involving ?OH, (d) verification of the great oxidation ability of the process to degrade mixtures containing all the carboxylics, upon variation of some experimental parameters such as current, concentration and cathode dimensions and, finally, (e) elucidation of a detailed reaction sequence for their mineralization, indicating the plausible pre-eminent pathways.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Electrochemical Fenton treatment of aromatic pollutants in aqueous medium always leads to the formation of short-chain carboxylic acids, which account for the slower degradation rate at the final stages of the process. In order to gain further insight into the fate of such compounds, bulk electrolyses of 200 mL aqueous solutions of eleven C1?C4 carboxylics, namely formic, glyoxylic, oxalic, acetic, glycolic, pyruvic, malonic, maleic, fumaric, succinic and malic acid have been carried out by electro-Fenton process with 0.1mM Fe2+ as catalyst, at room temperature and pH 3.0, applying a constant current and using an open and undivided cell equipped with a carbon-felt cathode and a Pt anode. In situ cathodic electrogeneration of Fenton?s reagent leads to the formation of the very oxidizing species hydroxyl radical (?OH) in the medium, allowing the degradation and total mineralization of all carboxylics studied. Various goals have been accomplished: (a) identification of the degradation intermediates for each carboxylic acid and study of their time course, (b) discussion and proposal of the reaction mechanisms under the action of ?OH/O2, (c) analysis of the decay kinetics and determination of the absolute rate constants, which agree well with those available in literature for processes involving ?OH, (d) verification of the great oxidation ability of the process to degrade mixtures containing all the carboxylics, upon variation of some experimental parameters such as current, concentration and cathode dimensions and, finally, (e) elucidation of a detailed reaction sequence for their mineralization, indicating the plausible pre-eminent pathways.
